sections.title: Started from the bottom
sections.content: My first encounter with software development was at 13 years old. In 2016, I signed up for a youth robotics tournament, in which my team and I won first place (3 years in a row :D). After my success, I got really interested in programming. In fact, I started going to a prestigious coding academy for young people in my town at the same time, although I was by far the youngest person to ever attend that course. I learned what programming is, and how to make my first website. It was truly the starting point of my career.

sections.title: Hard work pays off
sections.content: Spending a few years learning is nothing to ignore, and as I found out, practicing programming at home in your free time really pays off. During this time, I had to decide which area to specialize in: frontend, backend, mobile... I said 'screw that' and just went with everything at once. Nowadays I consider myself a full stack developer, capable of making web, desktop, and mobile applications, as well as backend servers, CLI tools, and games in multiple languages. It wasn't easy, mind you. I was going to high school at the same time and I was also competing in multiple tournaments organized by my school (in which our team, of course, won 2 times in a row).

sections.title: The snowball effect
sections.content: It was 2022. School was ending, and I really had to get serious about my future career. I was still very cautious when looking for jobs or education opportunities, because I was unsure what I was even getting myself into. Thankfully, I didn't have to fret too much about that. I got offered a summer internship at a company I really like! To me, this was practically a godsend, and I learned a lot. In fact, I even got a job offer at the same company, which was quite a new experience to me. I was still looking to improve my knowledge and to get formally educated, so unfortunately I had to decline the job offer in favor of going to university. What follows after, I am yet to find out.
